analytic.title: ORIGINAL RESEARCH • BREAST IMAGING

biblStruct.note: Received March 5, 2018; revision requested April 6; revision received July 1; accepted July 3

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: To evaluate the diagnostic performance of quantitative parameters derived from dual-energy CT for the preoperative diagnosis of metastatic sentinel lymph nodes (SLNs) in participants with breast cancer.
For this prospective study, dual-phase contrast agent-enhanced CT was performed in female participants with breast cancer from June 2015 to December 2017.
Quantitative dual-energy CT parameters and morphologic parameters were compared between metastatic and nonmetastatic SLNs.
The quantitative parameters were fitted to univariable and multivariable logistic regression models.
The diagnostic role of morphologic and quantitative parameters was analyzed by receiver operating characteristic curves and compared by using the McNemar test.
Results: This study included 193 female participants (mean age, 47.6 years 6 10.1; age range, 22-79 years).

Quantitative dualenergy CT parameters including slope of the spectral Hounsfield unit curve (l Hu ) measured at both arterial and venous phases, normalized iodine concentration at both arterial and venous phase, and normalized effective atomic number at the venous phase were higher in metastatic than in nonmetastatic SLNs (P value range, .001 to .031).

Univariable and multivariable logistic regression analyses showed that venous phase l Hu (in Hounsfield units per kiloelectron-volt) was the best single parameter for the detection of metastatic SLNs.
The accuracy of the venous phase l Hu for detecting metastatic SLNs was 90.5% on a per-lymph node basis and 87.0% on a per-patient basis.
The accuracy and specificity at venous phase l Hu was higher than their counterparts in the morphologic parameters (P , .001).
Dual-energy CT is a complementary means for the preoperative identification of sentinel lymph nodes metastases in participants with breast cancer.
evant relationships.
J.M. disclosed no relevant relationships.
J.S. disclosed no relevant relationships.
reast cancer is the most frequently occurring malignancy and the leading cause of cancer-related deaths among women (1).
Identification of the axillary lymph node status is important not only for predicting the prognosis but also for treatment planning and decision making (2,3).
Patients with axillary lymph nodal metastasis have a worse prognosis (4).

Preoperative detection of metastatic axillary lymph nodes allows the surgeon to proceed directly to axillary lymph node dissection by avoiding an unnecessary biopsy in the axillary sentinel lymph node (SLN) and by obviating the need for a second axillary surgical procedure (2).

It can also improve the ability to plan for radiation therapy after mastectomy and possible neoadjuvant chemotherapy, and it can improve the ability to counsel the patient about immediate breast reconstruction (5).
Lymphatic drainage from the breast to axillary lymph nodes first reaches the SLN (6); a metastasis in the SLN may accurately predict the overall staging of axillary lymph nodes.
Currently, SLN biopsy replaced axillary lymph node dissection as the reference standard for staging the axillary lymph node status in patients who are clinically node negative (6).
SLN biopsy reduces the risk of postoperative lymphedema.
However, it remains invasive and is associated with certain morbidities (ie, lymphedema, seroma, hematoma, shoulder dysfunction, nerve damage, upper arm numbness, tingling, and pain) (7,8).

A preoperative, noninvasive method that can be substituted for SLN biopsy is highly desirable, particularly when there is no overt involvement of axillary lymph nodes in the clinical and imaging workup (9).
The diagnostic performance of preoperative US, MRI, and PET are considered insufficient as alternatives to SLN biopsy (2).
CT is routinely performed in patients with advanced disease.
CT imaging is less frequently used in the axilla in patients with breast tumors (2), and therefore radiologists have less experience with CT for this purpose.
Moreover, the morphologic criterion of metastatic lymph nodes at conventional CT cannot accurately predict the status of lymph nodes (10,11).
Thus, an imaging method images of arterial and venous phases for morphologic evaluation and preoperative axillary lymph node locating and labeling.

The dual-energy CT data sets were reconstructed into monochromatic image sets with photon energies ranging from 40 to 140 keV, iodine-based material-decomposition images, water-based material decomposition images, and effective atomic number images.
Preoperative Locating and Labeling Axillary lymph nodes were located according to the standard of the axillary regional lymph nodal level system (2).
All visible lymph nodes at axillary level I were labeled for evaluation of SLNs.
The details of locating and labeling are provided in Appendix E1 (online).

Preoperative locating and labeling was performed by consensus by a radiologist and a breast surgeon (X.Z., with 6 years of experience in breast and chest diagnostic imaging and 5 years of experience in postreconstruction imaging, and H.R.D., with 3 years of experience in breast diagnostic imaging and 6 years of experience in breast surgery, respectively).
All level I lymph nodes were numbered according to the following order: from inferior to superior, from anterior to posterior, and from medial to lateral.
A three-dimensional lymph node map was reconstructed for each participant by using image fusion technology on the workstation (AW 4.6; GE Healthcare).
An example three-dimensional lymph node map in a single participant is shown in Figure 1.
Before the operation, preoperative three-dimensional CT maps were given to the surgeons.
During the operation, all participants underwent SLN biopsy by using the blue-dye method (Appendix E1 [online]) as previously described (18).

On the basis of a previously reported method (17), the lymph nodes at axillary level I were identified according to their location by the same breast surgeon (H.R.D.) who referred to preoperative three-dimensional CT maps and labeled these lymph nodes in the same order as defined with preoperative labeling on CT images.
All blue-stained lymph nodes were deemed to be SLNs and were selected for further quantitative dual-energy CT analysis.
These SLNs were excised level by level along with surrounding tissues and removed in the same order as defined with preoperative labeling.

During identifying and labeling, the nodal size and relationship to adjacent structures (axillary artery and vein, lateral thoracic artery and vein, and subscapular artery and vein) were used to calibrate their locations in the dissected blocks with preoperative three-dimensional maps.
If several nodes lay close to one another, they were discriminated by size and morphologic character.
Matched SLNs were labeled by using the same labels as those on CT images and were followed up by pathologic examination.
Each labeled SLN was analyzed as previously reported (19).
Each node was recorded as benign, isolated tumor cells, micrometastasis, or macrometastasis (Appendix E1 [online]).

Morphologic analysis of SLNs was performed by two radiologists (J.S. and Z.H.Y., with 18 and 10 years of experience in Abbreviations SLN = sentinel lymph node, l Hu = slope of the spectral Hounsfield unit curve

The slope of the spectral Hounsfield unit curve at venous phase and derived at dual-energy CT can differentiate metastatic from nonmetastatic axillary sentinel lymph nodes in participants with breast cancer.
Dual-energy CT imaging is a complementary and noninvasive means for the preoperative identification of axillary sentinel lymph nodal metastases in patients with breast cancer.
with the capability to help detect axillary nodal metastasis with accuracy remains to be developed.

Recently, quantitative parameters derived from spectral imaging data on the basis of dual-energy CT have proven to be useful for the diagnosis (12)(13)(14)(15) and nodal staging in several types of tumors (16,17).
However, the value of quantitative parameters from dual-energy CT in the preoperative diagnosis of SLN metastasis in patients with breast cancer remains elusive.
We hypothesized that quantitative parameters derived from dual-energy CT can be used for preoperative diagnosis of metastatic SLNs in patients with breast cancer.
In our study, dualenergy CT was performed in participants with breast cancer, and the quantitative parameters of axillary lymph nodes were obtained.

The purpose of our study was to determine the diagnostic performance of quantitative parameters from dual-energy CT in the preoperative diagnosis of metastatic SLNs in participants with breast cancer.

Our prospective, single-center study was approved by the ethics committee of Sun Yat-Sen Memorial Hospital (Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, China), and written informed consent was obtained from all participants.

From June 2015 to December 2017, 321 consecutive women who were suspected of having breast cancer at mammographic or US examination and who had been instructed to undergo dual-energy CT for evaluation of the status of mediastinal lymph nodes, potential lung metastasis, or underlying lung tuberculosis were enrolled.

Eligibility criteria for enrollment included a first diagnosis of breast cancer, women who had not undergone biopsy of axillary lymph nodes before the initial CT examination, women who had no history of chemotherapy and radiation therapy in the axillary space, and women who were not pregnant and had no general contraindication for CT imaging.
The clinical and pathologic features of these 321 participants are described in Appendix E1 (online).
Participants underwent dual-phase contrast agent-enhanced chest dual-energy CT by using a 64 multi-detector row CT scanner (Discovery CT750HD; GE Healthcare, Waukesha, Wis).
CT scanning was performed within 1 week before the surgical procedure.
The detailed CT protocol is provided in Appendix E1 (online).

We reconstructed 70-keV monochromatic 339 40 keV and that at 70 keV divided by the energy difference (30 keV), was calculated as follows: l Hu = (HU 40keV 2 HU 70keV )/30 keV (17), where HU 40keV represents the CT value measured on 40-keV images and HU 70keV stands for the CT value measured on 70-keV images.
Details are provided in Appendix E1 (online).

For the labeled SLNs in each participant, the normalized iodine concentration, normalized effective atomic number, and l Hu values were measured on both arterial and venous phase contrast-enhanced images.
The agreement of the evaluation of quantitative parameters from dual-energy CT between the two readers was calculated by using the intraclass correlation coefficient.
Morphologic and quantitative dual-energy CT parameters were compared between metastatic and nonmetastatic SLNs.
Univariable and multivariable binary logistic regression analyses were used to determine the independent predictive dual-energy CT parameters for the diagnosis of SLN metastasis.

Receiver operating characteristic curve analysis was used to evaluate the diagnostic ability of morphologic parameters and quantitative parameters both on per-lymph node basis and on per-patient basis.
The sensitivity, specificity, and accuracy were calculated, and the optimal threshold was determined by the Youden index.
The sensitivity, specificity, and accuracy of the morphologic parameters and quantitative dual-energy CT parameters were compared by using the McNemar test.
Details of statistical analysis are in Appendix E1 (online).

Among 321 participants enrolled, 128 participants were excluded because of acceptance of a nodal biopsy before CT scanning (n = 26), with pathologic analysis-proven biopsy of benign breast lesions (n = 80), with no SLN biopsy during surgery (n = 16), and with pathologic analysis-proven micrometastases in the lymph node (n = 6).
Finally, 193 participants (mean breast and chest imaging diagnosis, respectively) who were blinded to the pathologic results of the lymph nodes and breast tumors.
The SLNs were assessed by using 70-keV monochromatic images on a picture archiving and communication system (Centricity RA1000 Workstation V.3.0;
GE Healthcare) with a multiplanar reconstruction technique available during evaluation.
SLNs were considered metastatic according to the previously described criteria (10,11,20,21).
The details of morphologic criteria are provided in Appendix E1 (online).
The two readers independently recorded the morphologic features of each SLN, and any disagreements were resolved in consensus.
For the longest and shortest nodal diameters, data from two readers were averaged for analysis.
The interval between readout sessions of the two radiologists was 1 week.

div.head: Quantitative Dual-Energy CT Parameters of SLNs

p.s: Dual-energy CT data were analyzed by using viewer software on a workstation (AW 4.6; GE Healthcare).

Two radiologists (C.S.Z. and X.D., with 4 years and 10 years of experience in breast and chest radiology, respectively) who were blinded to the patient information and histopathologic results of the SLNs independently performed the measurements.
The interval between readout sessions of these two readers was 2 weeks.
Dual-energy parameters were measured by placing a region of interest that encompassed the entire SLN (Fig 2).

Quantitative parameters including CT values measured on monochromatic images, the iodine concentration (in milligrams per cubed centimeter) derived from iodine-based material decomposition images, and the effective atomic number were calculated by workstation software.

The iodine concentration and effective atomic number of the SLN were respectively divided by the iodine concentration and effective atomic number of the aorta to obtain the normalized iodine concentration and normalized effective atomic number.

The slope of the spectral Hounsfield unit curve (l Hu , in Hounsfield unit per kiloelectron-volt), which is defined as the difference between the CT value at The morphologic parameters of 337 SLNs and their diagnostic abilities on a per-lymph-node basis are shown in Table 1.
Their diagnostic abilities compared on per-patient basis are shown in Table E3 (online).
The shortest diameter and the longest diameter to the shortest diameter ratio had a low-to-moderate diagnostic sensitivity, specificity, and accuracy.
The highest diagnostic accuracy that was achieved by the shortest diameter or longest diameter to the shortest diameter ratio was 65.9% on per-lymph-node basis and 67.9% on per-patient basis.
In addition, 269 non-blue-stained lymph nodes at axillary level I were dissected in 55 participants who had metastatic SLNs.

We identified 13.7% (37 of 269) non-blue-stained lymph nodes as metastatic according to morphologic parameters at dual-energy CT, among which 38% (14 of 37) were confirmed at pathologic examination as metastasis (Table E4 [online]).
Intraclass correlation coefficients of quantitative dual-energy CT parameters between the two readers are shown in Table E5 (online).
Interreader agreement for the evaluation carcinomas; 86.5% (167 of 193) participants had carcinoma in situ, T1-, and T2-stage carcinoma according to the established TNM staging system (22).
A total of 1347 lymph nodes at axillary level I were labeled on the preoperative CT images.
Among them, 25.0% (337 of 1347) of lymph nodes were blue-stained (mean number of blue-stained lymph nodes, 1.7 6 1.2; one to eight nodes for each participant) and were dissected.
During surgery, the 337 lymph nodes were successfully matched and labeled.
These 337 SLNs were divided into two groups according to the histopathologic results: metastatic SLNs (macrometastasis, 76 SLNs) and nonmetastatic SLNs (benign, 261 SLNs).
Example dual-energy CT images in two participants are shown in Figures 4 and 5.
In addition, 146 of the 193 participants underwent dual-energy CT, US, and mammography.
By comparing on a per-patient basis, dual-energy CT helped to detect the highest number of abnormal lymph nodes and had the highest diagnostic accuracy (P , .001;
Table E2 [online]).
Further comparison on per-patient basis showed that the diagnostic accuracy (87.0%) of venous phase l Hu remained the highest (Table 4; Fig 6, B).
As shown in Tables 3 and 4, the accuracy of the venous phase l Hu was 90.5% on per-lymph node basis and 87.0% on per-patient basis.

As shown in Table 1 and Table E3, the highest diagnostic accuracy of the morphologic parameters (shortest diameter and longest-to-shortest diameter ratio) was 65.9% on per-lymph node basis and 67.9% on per-patient basis.
The venous phase l Hu had a higher specificity and higher accuracy than the shortest diameter and longest-toshortest diameter ratio both on per-lymph node and on perpatient basis (P , .001).

Our study showed that quantitative dual-energy CT parameter l Hu measured at venous phase had a higher diagnostic ability (including higher specificity and accuracy) in of the quantitative parameters was good.

Quantitative parameters between metastatic and nonmetastatic SLNs are in Table 2. Arterial phase l Hu , venous phase l Hu , arterial phase normalized iodine concentration, venous phase normalized iodine concentration, and venous phase normalized effective atomic number of metastatic SLNs were higher than those of nonmetastatic SLNs (P value range, ,.001 to .031).

Univariable logistic regression analysis showed that arterial phase l Hu , venous phase l Hu , venous phase normalized iodine concentration, and venous phase normalized effective atomic number were risk factors for predicting metastatic SLNs (P , .001).

Further multivariable logistic regression analysis showed that among these four quantitative parameters, venous phase l Hu was the independent predictor for metastatic SLNs (odds ratio, 9.9; 95% confidence interval: 5.2, 18.7; P , .001;
Table E6 [online]).

Receiver operating characteristic curve analysis showed that venous phase l Hu had the highest differential diagnostic capability, with an accuracy of 90.5% (Table 3; lymph nodal metastases to help the surgeon decide when to proceed directly to axillary lymph node dissection (2).
Preoperative US is the primary nonsurgical method (5) but it had a moderate, unstable sensitivity (mean sensitivity, 48.4%; range, 26.4%-75.9%)
and a high specificity (mean specificity, 96.5%; range, 88.4%-98.1%)
when lymph node morphologic structure was used as the criterion for positivity (23,24).
MRI enhances the detection of potentially abnormal lymph nodes (2).

However, morphologic features showed poor discriminatory power for the diagnosis of axillary metastases even by using a 7.0-T MRI system (sensitivity, 35%-88%; specificity, 32%-70%; positive predictive value, 24%-26%; and negative predictive value, 78%-91%) (25).
Quantitative parameters such as T1, T2, and apparent the preoperative identification of axillary SLN metastasis in participants with breast cancer than the conventional morphologic parameters.

The main goal for preoperative imaging in participants with breast cancer is to identify the presence of axillary invasion are limited because of the lower prevalence of these signs in participants with breast cancer.

Quantitative dual-energy CT parameters such as l Hu , normalized iodine concentration, and normalized effective atomic number have been suggested to be helpful for the preoperative identification of metastatic lymph nodes in patients with gastric cancer (16), lung cancer (27), and cervical lymphadenopathy (17,28,29).

In our study, arterial phase l Hu , venous phase l Hu , arterial phase normalized iodine concentration, venous phase normalized iodine concentration, and venous phase normalized effective atomic number of metastatic SLNs were higher than those of nonmetastatic SLNs.
Multivariable analysis showed that venous phase l Hu was an independent single predictor for discriminating metastatic SLNs from nonmetastatic SLNs.
Compared with the morphologic parameters, venous phase l Hu could significantly improve the diagnostic ability of CT, especially by improving the accuracy to 90.5% on per-lymph-node basis.
Further comparison on a per-patient basis showed a high diagnostic accuracy (87.0%) of the venous phase l Hu .

A preoperative quantitative parameter with such high accuracy may help surgeons to reduce unnecessary axillary lymph node dissection and preoperative biopsy, and help radiologists improve the confidence of diagnosis and avoid subjective bias related to experience.

l Hu can provide quantitative information about tissue composition, and is superior to conventional CT values, overcoming the limitations of attenuation-based conventional single-energy CT imaging (30,31).
It has been shown (32,33) that l Hu can be used to differentiate iodine from soft tissues on the basis of their differences in attenuation at different energy levels.
diffusion coefficient were suggested to be insufficient for the differentiation (25,26).
PET and PET/CT are not routinely used in tumors at clinical T1 and T2 stage, and there is a lack of experience in PET and PET/CT imaging of the axilla in patients with breast tumors (2).

For morphologic analysis, a shortest diameter of 5 mm or greater and ratio of the longest diameter to the shortest diameter of 2 or less are the most widely used size criteria in differentiating metastatic and nonmetastatic lymph nodes at convectional CT and MRI (10,11,21,25).

Although these criteria had a high specificity, the diagnostic sensitivity was poor (12% for the shortest diameter  5 mm) or moderate (60% for the ratio of the longest diameter to the shortest diameter  2:1) (10).
In our study, the diagnostic performance of size criteria was also moderate for differentiating metastatic from nonmetastatic SLNs.
Therefore, it remains difficult to accurately predict the nodal status according to the size criterion alone (10,25).
In addition, the diagnostic value of other CT features such as early strong contrast enhancement, absence of a nodal hilum, abnormal cortex, and extracapsular Our study had limitations.
First, micrometastatic SLNs were not included.
However, the number of micrometastatic SLNs in our study was small (n = 6) and the tiny area of tumor tissue (2 mm) in micrometastatic lymph nodes was difficult to discern on CT images.
Second, only blue-stained SLNs were evaluated and other non-blue-stained lymph nodes were not included in our study.

Indeed, previous studies (34) with US showed that SLN biopsy has a false-negative rate of about 10% for helping to predict the status of axillary lymph nodes and cannot identify all metastatic lymph nodes.
However, the presence of the false-negative rate has been always a problem in SLN biopsy (35).
As a result of high overall accuracy (96.9%), sensitivity (91.2%), and specificity (100%), SLN biopsy is still considered a reliable axillary staging technique (35).
Third, unenhanced dual-energy CT scanning was not applied in our study.
An unenhanced CT scan would lead to a 30% radiation dose increase.
Moreover, a previous study (17) showed that there are no differences in the quantitative dualenergy CT parameters between metastatic and nonmetastatic lymph nodes on the basis of unenhanced images.

In conclusion, our study showed that l Hu at venous phase derived at dual-energy CT had a high diagnostic performance for the preoperative diagnosis of SLN metastases in participants with breast cancer.
Dual-energy CT can be used as a complementary noninvasive means for the preoperative identification of SLN metastases in patients with breast cancer.
Note.-Data in parentheses are numerator/denominator and data in brackets are 95% confidence intervals.
l Hu = slope of the spectral Hounsfield unit curve, AUC = area under the curve, nIC = normalized iodine concentration, nZ eff = normalized effective atomic number, SLN = sentinel lymph node.

Figure 1: Representative three-dimensional lymph node maps at axillary level I show the relationships between lymph nodes (green) and the lateral thoracic artery (black arrowheads), pectoralis minor muscle ( * , purple), and subscapular artery (black arrows) and its terminal branches including the circumflex scapular artery (white arrows) and the thoracodorsal artery (white arrowheads) in the, A, anteroposterior view and, B, right lateral-medial view in a 49-year-old woman with right breast cancer.
All lymph nodes were numbered in the following order: from inferior to superior, from anterior to posterior, and from medial to lateral.
Numbers 1-5 represent the serial numbers of labeled lymph nodes at axillary level I.
Figure 3: Flowchart shows the strategy for sentinel lymph node analysis and data processing in this study.
SLN = sentinel lymph node.
Figure 2: Measurement of dual-energy CT parameters in the same patient as in Figure 1.
A, An ovoid region of interest (red; area, 78.10 mm 2 ) placed on a metastatic sentinel lymph node (SLN; 3 [L3]) on a contrast-enhanced 70-keV monochromatic image.
The inset is an iodine-based pseudo-colorized image of L3 (iodine concentration, 2.75 mg/cm 3 ).
B, An ovoid region of interest (yellow; area, 13.87 mm 2 ) placed on a nonmetastatic SLN (5 [L5]) on a contrast-enhanced 70-keV monochromatic image.
The inset is an iodine-based pseudo-colorized image of L5 (iodine concentration, 1.67 mg/cm 3 ).
C, Graph shows the spectra Hounsfield unit curve of the metastatic SLN (L3, in red) and nonmetastatic SLN (L5, in yellow).
The slope of the spectral Hounsfield unit curve (l Hu ) of L3 is higher than that of L5 (6.03 HU/keV vs 3.52 HU/keV).
Figure 4: Representative dual-energy CT images in a 57-year-old woman with right breast cancer.

Three-dimensional lymph node maps at axillary level I show the relationships between lymph nodes (green areas in A and B) and the lateral thoracic artery (arrowheads), pectoralis minor muscle ( * , purple areas in A and B), and the subscapular artery (arrows) and its terminal branch in the, A, anteroposterior view and, B, right mediolateral view.

Numbers 1-5 represent the serial numbers of labeled lymph nodes at axillary level I. Representative venous phase contrast-enhanced dual-energy CT images show that iodine concentration and slope of the spectral Hounsfield unit curve (l Hu ) were different in metastatic (L2) and nonmetastatic (L4) lymph nodes.
C, Contrast-enhanced 70-keV monochromatic image and iodine-based pseudo-colorized image (inset) of a metastatic lymph node (L2 area, 67.96 mm 2 ; iodine concentration, 2.96 mg/cm 3 ).
D, Contrast-enhanced 70-keV monochromatic image and iodine-based pseudo-colorized image (inset) of a nonmetastatic lymph node (L4 area, 26.92 mm 2 ; iodine concentration, 2.17 mg/cm 3 ).
E, Graph shows the spectra Hounsfield unit curve of metastatic (L2, red) and nonmetastatic (L4, yellow) lymph nodes.
The l Hu of the metastatic lymph node is higher than that of the nonmetastatic lymph node (5.53 HU/keV vs 3.13 HU/keV).
Figure 5: Representative dual-energy CT images in a 51-year-old woman with right breast cancer.

Three-dimensional lymph node maps at axillary level I show the relationships between lymph nodes (green areas in A and B) and lateral thoracic artery (arrowheads), subscapular artery (arrows), and pectoralis minor muscle ( * , purple areas in A and B) in the, A, anteroposterior view and, B, right mediolateral view.

Numbers 1-5 represent the serial numbers of labeled lymph nodes at axillary level I. Representative venous phase contrast-enhanced dual-energy CT images show that iodine concentration and slope of the spectral Hounsfield unit curve (l Hu ) were significantly different in metastatic (L2) and nonmetastatic (L3) lymph nodes.
C, Contrast-enhanced 70-keV monochromatic image and iodine-based pseudo-colorized image (inset) of a metastatic lymph node (L2 area, 52.85 mm 2 ; iodine concentration, 2.95 mg/cm 3 ).
D, Contrast-enhanced 70-keV monochromatic image and iodine-based pseudo-colorized image (inset) of a nonmetastatic lymph node (L3 area, 9.15 mm 2 ; iodine concentration, 1.98 mg/cm 3 ).
E, Graph shows the spectral Hounsfield unit curve of metastatic (L2, red) and nonmetastatic (L3, yellow) lymph nodes.
The l Hu of the metastatic lymph node is higher than that of the nonmetastatic lymph node (5.46 HU/keV vs 3.29 HU/keV).

Figure 6: Receiver operating characteristic curves of the slope of the spectral Hounsfield unit curve at venous phase for differentiating metastatic and nonmetastatic sentinel lymph nodes (on a per-lymph-node basis) in, A, patients with breast cancer and for differentiating, B, patients with sentinel lymph node metastasis and those without metastasis (on per-patient basis).
Accu = accuracy, AUC = area under the curve, sens = sensitivity, spec = specificity.
Note.-Data in parentheses are numerator/denominator and data in brackets are 95% confidence intervals.
The unit for the threshold of parameter for arterial phase l Hu and venous phase l Hu is Hounsfield unit per kiloelectron-volt.
SLN = sentinel lymph node, AUC = area under the curve, l Hu = slope of the spectral Hounsfield unit curve, nIC = normalized iodine concentration, nZ eff = normalized effective atomic number.
* Data in parenthesis are numerator/denominator; data in brackets are 95% confidence intervals.
Axillary Sentinel Lymph Nodes in Breast Cancer: Quantitative Evaluation at Dual-Energy CT

We also thank Yun Huang, PhD, for her kind help with the statistical analysis.
